title: 🗓️ Week 3 How to write
text:
Tips
- Find the wrong journal
- Say things that people have already known
- Don’t let your reader know your purpose
- Say thing that are not of any use
- Don’t explain why your did it nor how
- Respond in a vague manner to reviewers’ comments

title: 🗓️ Week 3 How to write
text:
Reading
How to get your papers rejected

title: 🗓️ Week 3 How to write
text:
Tips
- Set specific times for writing
- Set both research and document goals
- Distinguish the different writing stages
- Avoid procrastination
- Resist perfectionism
- Stay connected and talk about it with others

title: 🗓️ Week 2Your paper’s outline
text:
Phenomenology
Phenomenological philosophy is interested in the general essences or persistent characteristics of things.
The empirical sciences are sciences of facts, interested in the concrete, singular, contextual and accidental qualities of phenomena.
https://www.mdpi.com/2076-0760/12/7/413

title: 🗓️ Week 2Your paper’s outline
text:
Heuristic process principles

The principle of evidence: researchers speak of a thing ‘only within the limits in which it then presents itself’.
The principle of ulteriority: researchers look for the real that remain shadowed or veiled.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Students
Please introduce yourselves
:::

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Knowledge
Knowledge refers to a theoretical and/or practical understanding of a subject.
It can be implicit or explicit; it can be more or less formal or systematic.
The study of knowledge is called epistemology.
Knowledge acquisition involves complex cognitive processes: perception, communication, and reasoning.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Science and technology (Sc&T)
Science uses empirical investigation to pursue many of the deepest questions pondered by scholars.
Engineering uses empirical knowledge to design and develop technology: products, processes, machines, and structures to solve the major challenges that face society.
Together, Sc&T are essential to advance the human condition.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Research
Research is a process of systematic inquiry that entails collection of data; documentation of critical information; and analysis and interpretation of that data/information.
Research is conducted in accordance with suitable methodologies set by specific professional fields and academic disciplines.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
What is a researcher? (1)
A researcher is someone who conducts systematic investigations and studies of materials and sources to establish facts, test hypotheses, reach new conclusions, and develop theories.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
What is a researcher? (2)

A fact is an indisputable observation of a natural or social phenomenon.
A hypothesis is an idea that we can test with further observations.
A theory is an explanation for what we observe, drawing together many facts and hypotheses.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text: What is a researcher? (3)

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Research methodology
It is a structured and scientific approach used to collect, analyze, and interpret quantitative or qualitative data to answer research questions or test hypotheses.
A research methodology is like a plan for carrying out research.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Quantitative research methodology
It focuses on measuring and testing numerical data.
This approach is good for reaching a large number of people in a short amount of time.
It helps in testing the causal relationships between variables, making predictions, and generalizing results to wider populations.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Qualitative research methodology
It examines opinions, behaviors, and experiences of people.
It collects and analyzes words and textual data.
It usually is time consuming due the time spent per participant. This method is used in exploratory research.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Mixed-method research methodology
It uses both quantitative and qualitative methodologies in the same study.
This method allows to validate findings, verify if results observed using both methods are complementary, and explain unexpected outcomes.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text: Research process

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text: Research cycle

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Primacy of the research question
A good research paper addresses a specific research question.
The research question—or study objective or research hypothesis—is the central organizing principle of the paper.
Whatever relates to the research question belongs in the paper; the rest doesn’t.

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Structure of the research paper

Introduction
Methods
Results
Discussion

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Introduction

Problem statement
Knowledge gaps
Research question

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Data & Methods

Study context & setting
Study design (framework, variables, sampling)
Population (or study area)
Workflow (data collection, data analysis)

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Results

Description of workflow outputs
Present key findings

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
Discussion

Answer the research question
Discuss findings from a broader perspective
Analyze strengths and limitations
Offer perspectives

title: 🗓️ Week 01 Introduction
text:
To do before next class

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO II
text:
Aprobación del curso Proyecto de Tesis
Avances significativos en el desarrollo de la tesis

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO II
text:
Aprobación del curso Proyecto de Tesis
Avances significativos en el desarrollo de la tesis

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO II
text:
DESCRIPCIÓN DE LA ASIGNATURA:






OBJETIVOS:






Entender los fundamentos de los diversos procesos requeridos en investigación en disciplinas geomáticas
Aprender a realizar una revisión crítica de literatura relevante para la tesis de maestría
Aprender a diseñar y escribir un artículo de investigación


COMPETENCIAS GENÉRICAS:

Capacidad para usar herramientas tecnológicas avanzadas
Capacidad de organización y planificación del tiempo
Capacidad de comunicación escrita y oral



COMPETENCIAS ESPECÍFICAS:

Capacidad de abstracción, análisis y síntesis
Capacidad de integrar y aplicar técnicas geoespaciales
Capacidad de lectura en inglés
Capacidad para organizar y planificar el tiempo
Capacidad para desarrollar pensamiento crítico, razonamiento espacial y calidad argumentativa



METODOLOGIA:

Lectura antes de la clase a cargo del estudiante
Presentación de conceptos, métodos y técnicas a cargo del profesor
Realización de lecturas, ejercicios de escritura y elaboración del artículo a cargo del estudiante

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO II
text:
CONTENIDO DETALLADO






Unidad 0 – Repaso de metodología de investigación






Unidad 1 - Fundamentos de investigación experimental


Unidad 2 - Lineamientos para realizar investigación reproducible


Unidad 3 – Revisión de literatura científica


Unidad 4 – Cómo escribir la introducción


Unidad 5 – Cómo sintetizar el estado del arte


Unidad 6 – Cómo describir la metodología


Unidad 7 - Cómo reportar los resultados


Unidad 8 - Cómo interpretar los resultados

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO II
text:
EVALUACIÓN DEL CURSO:






Important






Entrega primer borrador del artículo (Mayo 13)
Entrega segundo borrador del artículo (Junio 9)
Entrega del artículo (Julio 8)
Sustentación del artículo (Julio 22)

text:
BIBLIOGRAFIA






Important





Alston J.M. & Rick J.A. 2021. A Beginner’s Guide to Conducting Reproducible Research, Bulletin of the Ecological Society of America (102) 2, 1-14 https://doi.org/10.1002/bes2.1801
Ferreira A. 2021. How to Write a Machine Learning Paper for (not so) Dummies. 8 pp. UNISI-DIISM, https://www.ic.unicamp.br/~ra023169/publications/misc1.pdf
Frees E.F. 2010. Regression Modeling with Actuarial and Financial Applications. 585 pp. Cambridge University Press The Edinburgh Building, Cambridge CB2 8RU, UK
Hansman R.J. & Ring U. 2019. Workflow: From photo-based 3-D reconstruction of remotely piloted aircraft images to a 3-D geological model, Geosphere (15) 4, pp. 1393-1408, https://doi.org/10.1130/GES02031.1
Hawkes C.H., Giovannoni G., Lechner-Scott J., Levy M. & Yeh E.A. 2021. How not to get your article published, Multiple Sclerosis and Related Disorders (54), 103226, ISSN 2211-0348, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msard.2021.103226.
Huemann M & , Pesämaa O. 2022. The first impression counts: The essentials of writing a convincing introduction, International Journal of Project Management (40) 7, pp. 827-830, ISSN 0263-7863, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijproman.2022.09.002.
Janke K.K., Wilby K.J. & Zavod R. 2020. Academic writing as a journey through “chutes and ladders”: How well are you managing your emotions?, Currents in Pharmacy Teaching and Learning, pp. 103-111, ISSN 1877-1297, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cptl.2019.11.001.
Kogure K, Takasaki Y (2019) GIS for empirical research design: An illustration with georeferenced point data. PLoS ONE 14(3)
Sholl D.S. 2019. Five Easy Ways To Make Your Research More Reproducible. Langmuir (35) 41, pp. 13257-13258, https://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/acs.langmuir.9b02963
Simon E., Osei-Ampofo M., Wachira B.W. & Kwan J. 2020. Getting accepted – Successful writing for scientific publication: a Research Primer for low- and middle-income countries, African Journal of Emergency Medicine (10) 2, pp. S154-S157, ISSN 2211-419X, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.afjem.2020.06.006.
Torres-Valladares D., Ballinas-García E., Villarreal-Reyes J., Morales-Álvarez V., Ortiz-del-Ánge C. 2022. Research papers 101: The do’s and don’ts of scientific writing, Materials Today: Proceedings (48) 1, pp. 107-114, ISSN 2214-7853, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matpr.2020.12.708.
Wardhana D.E.C, Yanti N., Susetyo S. & Suhartono S. 2019. Student’s Problem in Writing Results and Discussion Section of Research Articles for International Journals, 1st International Conference on Educational Sciences and Teacher Profession (ICETeP 2018) https://doi.org/10.2991/icetep-18.2019.41
Zelner J., Broen K., August E. 2022. A guide to backward paper writing for the data sciences, Patterns (3) 3, 100423, ISSN 2666-3899, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.patter.2021.100423.

title: 2020771 - SEMINARIO 2
text:
📑 Course Brief
Focus: the focus of this course is to gain knowledge on research methods and scientific writing. This academic activity aims to strengthen students’ abilities to document & communicate their geospatial research results.
How: reading, learning by doing and writing


🎯 Learning Objectives

Appraise the research processes used to build up science
Understand the principles of experimental research
Get to know how to conduct a literature review
Learn to write a scientific report


Select Academic Year/Term:
 2025
